nodes.body:
### PR summary [4414ce61e1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15120/commits/4414ce61e1d464b3bfb2577541caaee67aa32316)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
As a meta comment: can you say more *why* is it useful for mathlib to compile under `debug.byAsSorry`? I trust you to have a reason, but would be interested in knowing more about it!
Um, I didn't check CI yet. As it fails, let me revise this to `maintainer delegate`: once you fixed the build, assuming only simple fixes, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf.

> As a meta comment: can you say more _why_ is it useful for mathlib to compile under `debug.byAsSorry`? I trust you to have a reason, but would be interested in knowing more about it!

Ah! Yes, it means we can test optimizations in Lean much more effectively. Currently it takes ~20 minutes even on a fast machine to see if a change in Lean affects performance deep in Mathlib.

If we can reliably compile Mathlib under `byAsSorry`, then we can maintain a branch of Mathlib with `byAsSorry` turned on everywhere except in a representative sample of slow files. This branch would then give a very fast benchmark.

> > As a meta comment: can you say more _why_ is it useful for mathlib to compile under `debug.byAsSorry`? I trust you to have a reason, but would be interested in knowing more about it!
> 
> Ah! Yes, it means we can test optimizations in Lean much more effectively. Currently it takes ~20 minutes even on a fast machine to see if a change in Lean affects performance deep in Mathlib.
> 
> If we can reliably compile Mathlib under `byAsSorry`, then we can maintain a branch of Mathlib with `byAsSorry` turned on everywhere except in a representative sample of slow files. This branch would then give a very fast benchmark.

This makes a lot of sense - thanks for explaining!
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

LGTM

It might also be useful for potential changes to variable inclusion mechanisms (at least if we go back to something similar to Lean 3's method).

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10092628914/job/27906651929)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10092628914/job/27906652563)

Still looks good, and now passes CI -> let me
maintainer merge
again

Also looks reasonable, thanks!
maintainer merge

Still looks good, and now passes CI -> let me
maintainer merge
again
This is a small readability regression to me, but only a small one -> I won't object to landing this.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: robustifying for debug.byAsSorry (part 3)
